_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PINNACLE FOODS CORP.
Fayetteville, Arkansas

RISK MANAGMENT PLAN 
Executive Summary


1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Pinnacle Foods Corp., we utilize anhydrous ammonia which is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The properties which make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also necessitate certain safety precautions.  Pinnacle Foods Corp. strives to protect all its valuable resources and assets - both personnel and property.  We live and have families in this community.  We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our community, existing natural resources, and the surrounding environment.  It is our policy to comply with Federal, State, and Local regulations.  Through continual, accurate training and various safety devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.

Our emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies.  We work in conjunction with the Fayetteville Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all affected neighbors.


2.  THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The primary purpose of our facility is the production of frozen foods.  We utilize anhydrous ammonia as the primary means for refrigeration, cooling and freezing.  A nationally recognized, reputable and professional ammonia delivery company is used to fill our main receiver tanks.  Steel piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration, cooling or freezing units.  Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The regulated substance used at our facility is anhydrous ammonia.  Our ammonia refrigeration system has a 330,000 pound capacity but our policy limits that storage and operating charge to 300,000 pounds, i.e., 90% of total capacity.


3.  THE WORST

CASE RELEASE SCENARIO(S) AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO(S), INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO

Worst Case Scenario
The worst case scenario would be failure of one of our three high pressure receivers. Pinnacle Foods Corp. policy restricts the maximum capacity of these 26,000 pound tank to 90% of capacity.  The maximum amount stored in any one of these tanks is 23,459 pounds.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as a two phase flow (gas and aerosol-ALOHA).
Distance to endpoint: 1.6 miles

Alternative Scenario
The alternative scenario would be the release of ammonia due to the failure of a pressure safety relief valve.  In the event that a safety relief valve should open, only a portion of the ammonia will likely be released from the system at any one time.  Under normal circumstances, it will be detected by nearby ammonia detectors, routine engineering systems checks and/or by workers in the area because of ammonia's low odor threshold.  Upon detection, the emergency valves shut-down release would engage and stop the flow or the on-screen monitoring system would alert personnel to manually shut the valve.  The maximum time of the release would be 10 minutes and maximum quantity released would be approximately 2,500 pounds of ammonia.  
Distance to endpoint:  .074053 miles (or 391 yards)
 

4.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

To date, this Pinnacle Foods Corp. facility has had one reportable release.  It occurred June 29, 1995, during some construction and remodeling.  It involved an outside contractor and resulted in various new process controls and revised emergency procedures.  Approximately 1,390 pounds of anhydrous ammonia was released and 530 people were evacuated from the facility.  

Off-site consequences were minimized due to several factors.  Pinnacle Foods Corp. has an in-house HAZMAT team that initially responded and worked in conjunction with the Fayetteville Fire

Department and HAZMAT teams.  Also, the release occurred inside the facility and much product was neutralized using CO2.  No evacuation was required for off-site receptors (persons off the Pinnacle Foods Corp. property).


5.  THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

The management of the RMP program will be handled by Mr. Fred McLane, Environmental Manager.  Mr. McLane will administrate in conjunction with the Pinnacle Foods Corp. management and personnel.  Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Fayetteville Fire Department and HAZMAT team.

In the event Mr. McLane is unavailable, the following personnel will have the authority to execute the Emergency Response Program elements:  Manager of Engineering/Maintenance; Supervisor of Boiler/Refrigeration.


6.  THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The ammonia refrigeration system design and construction is based upon accepted and proven engineering design practices for a safe operating refrigeration plant.  The system was designed and constructed to meet the Uniform Building Code, Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Fire Code, SHARAE Standard 15 and the National Electrical Code.  Shut-off valves are strategically located throughout the refrigeration system to allow emergency shut-off, periodic maintenance and repair.  Depending on location and use in the system, pressure vessels are ASME rated and fitted with either a single or dual safety relief valve as required by ASME.

The Pinnacle Foods Corp. facility complies with applicable Federal, State and Local regulations including the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule.  Our personnel are trained about this during our Hazard Communications Training and through access to our Written Programs.  Our Refrigeration Maintenance operators receive a combination of classroom training plus On-The-Job (OTJ) training.  They are given written tests and

are able to demonstrate proper job skills and knowledge.


7.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We work very closely with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Fayetteville Fire Department and HAZMAT team on emergency preparedness.  We meet periodically with representatives of each to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns.


 
8.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Currently, Pinnacle Foods Corp. trains and tests all refrigeration technicians.  Our preventative maintenance program is above standard and our total ammonia Process Safety Program is reviewed annually and updated periodically.  Our program is improved continuously through annual updating of our written program and annual training of our technicians.  We also take advantage of new technologies when safer and more economical alternatives are available.


9.  RMP*SUBMIT(TM) INFORMATION

The following pages contain the information submitted by Pinnacle Foods Corp. to the EPA on June 18, 1999.  There are nine sections and an Executive Summary.  This information was submitted via diskette using RMP*SubmitTM.  RMP*SubmitTM is developed and distributed by the Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Office (CEPPO).


10.  COMMUNICATION TO THE PUBLIC

Pinnacle Foods Corp. will be submitting this RMP plan to the Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Fayetteville Fire Department in addition to the submittal to the EPA.  Pinnacle Foods Corp. have representation on the LEPC which helps assure a continued presence with that organization in the community.

Included in this section is any information that has been or will be distributed to the public or the LEPC in addition to the data already noted in this plan.
